abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Poverty Alleviation
            Project for Sri Lanka was unsatisfactory. The project only
            partially achieved its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was partially successful,
            sustainability is unlikely, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was deficient.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            implementing poverty alleviation activities through NGOs
            operating under an apex semi-government organization is an
            extremely complex and demanding task. Second, the economic
            rationale and technical feasibility of project components
            needs to be analyzed and developed with care. Third, pilot
            projects, as a basis for testing strategies and approaches,
            can play a central role in facilitating overall project
            success. Fourth, a high quality and effective MIS, including
            regular beneficiary surveys, is essential to ensure
            efficient project implementation and achievement of
            objectives. Fifth, it is important to exploit synergy
            effects. Sixth, it is important to provide training to NGOs
            and POs in poverty alleviation activities. Finally, the
            Government's broad strategy for poverty alleviation in
            Sri Lanka underwent a major shift in emphasis mid-way
            through the project's lifespan.
